verses.text: When Jesus saw the crowds, he went up on the mountain. After he sat down, his disciples came to him.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches from the mountain, reminiscent of Moses receiving the law on Sinai, underscoring his authoritative fulfillment and reinterpretation of the law.

verses.text: He opened his mouth and taught them, saying:
verses.comment: The phrase 'opened his mouth' signals a solemn discourse, marking the importance and gravity of his teaching.

verses.text: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: 'Poor in spirit' refers to humility and spiritual dependence on God, a disposition that opens one to receive God's reign. This echoes prophecies about God favoring the humble.

verses.text: Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.
verses.comment: Comfort here is both present consolation and hope of final restoration. Jesus draws from Isaiah's prophecy about healing the brokenhearted.

verses.text: Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth.
verses.comment: Meekness is a virtue of gentleness and patience, showing strength restrained for God's purpose. The promise echoes Old Testament assurance for the righteous.

verses.text: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be satisfied.
verses.comment: Righteousness here is both personal holiness and justice. Jesus promises fulfillment for active seekers.

verses.text: Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy.
verses.comment: Mercy is central to true Christian life, echoing God's attribute and teaching that forgiveness is reciprocal (cf. Matt 6:14).

verses.text: Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.
verses.comment: Purity of heart means singleness of devotion. The promise to 'see God' ties to visions of divine glory in the Old Testament and foreshadows beatific vision.

verses.text: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God.
verses.comment: Peacemaking involves reconciliation, like Christ who is the ultimate peacemaker. Being called sons of God affirms adoption and participation in divine nature (cf. John 1:12).

verses.text: Blessed are those persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Suffering for righteousness links to prophetic tradition; ultimate vindication and heavenly inheritance is promised.

verses.text: Blessed are you when others insult you, persecute you, and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me.
verses.comment: 'Because of me' marks the unique vocation of discipleship and union with Christ's own suffering.

verses.text: Rejoice and be glad, for your reward is great in heaven; for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.
verses.comment: Jesus places his followers in continuity with the prophets, encouraging joy through participation in God's salvation history.

verses.text: You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its taste, how will it be made salty again? It is no longer good for anything except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot.
verses.comment: Salt symbolized covenant faithfulness (Lev. 2:13). Disciples must maintain their distinctiveness or risk spiritual irrelevance.

verses.text: You are the light of the world. A city set on a hill cannot be hidden.
verses.comment: Disciples share in Christ's light-bearing mission (John 8:12). The 'city on a hill' points to the gathered visible community of believers.

verses.text: No one lights a lamp and puts it under a basket, but on a stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house.
verses.comment: The lamp illustrates the outward witness of faithful disciples.

verses.text: In the same way, let your light shine before others, so that they may see your good works and give glory to your Father who is in heaven.
verses.comment: Good works glorify God and reveal his presence to the world; community and visibility of faith are essential.

verses.text: Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets. I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them.
verses.comment: Jesus claims authority over the law but fulfills and perfects it, revealing his role as the divine lawgiver, greater than Moses.

verses.text: For truly, I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not the smallest letter or stroke will pass from the Law until all is accomplished.
verses.comment: The perfection and continuity of the Law endure; Jesus upholds its divine authority, yet reveals its ultimate spiritual fulfillment in himself.

verses.text: Therefore, whoever breaks one of the least of these commandments and teaches others to do so will be called least in the kingdom of heaven. But whoever keeps and teaches them will be called great in the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: Instruction and practice both matter for standing before God; visible teaching office is highlighted.

verses.text: For I tell you, unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven.
verses.comment: True righteousness is more than outward observance; interior transformation is necessary—a hint at sacramental grace.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not murder; and whoever murders will be subject to judgment.’
verses.comment: Jesus quotes the Decalogue, then deepens the commandment.

verses.text: But I say to you, everyone who is angry with his brother will be subject to judgment. Whoever calls his brother ‘Raca’ will be subject to the council. Whoever says, ‘You fool,’ will be liable to the fire of Gehenna.
verses.comment: Jesus deepens the command from mere external action to internal disposition and speech, which brings spiritual consequence. He speaks as lawgiver.

verses.text: Therefore, if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you,
verses.comment: Altar reference presumes ongoing temple ritual and anticipates Christian worship, where reconciliation is prerequisite for sacrifice.

verses.text: Leave your gift there in front of the altar. First go and be reconciled to your brother; then come and offer your gift.
verses.comment: Spiritual reconciliation is required before liturgical action; the continuity of worship and relationship is emphasized.

verses.text: Agree quickly with your adversary while you are on the way to court, lest your adversary hand you over to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you be thrown into prison.
verses.comment: The call for prompt reconciliation has both spiritual and practical wisdom, warning against hardened conflict.

verses.text: Truly I say to you, you will never get out until you have paid the last penny.
verses.comment: Completion of penalty hints at principle of divine justice, with possible spiritual implications for purification.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall not commit adultery.’
verses.comment: Another Decalogue command is cited, prepared for deepening by Christ.

verses.text: But I say to you, everyone who looks at a woman to lust after her has already committed adultery with her in his heart.
verses.comment: Jesus raises the demand to internal purity, not just external conformity.

verses.text: If your right eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away; for it is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to be thrown into Gehenna.
verses.comment: 'Gehenna' is an image of judgment. Radical action is urged to preserve spiritual life.

verses.text: And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away; for it is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into Gehenna.
verses.comment: Similar to v.29, stressing the urgency and seriousness of spiritual discipline.

verses.text: It was also said, ‘Whoever divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.’
verses.comment: Divorce law is cited; Jesus is about to give deeper teaching.

verses.text: But I say to you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, causes her to become an adulteress, and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
verses.comment: Jesus’ teaching on marriage heightens the indissoluble bond; the exception is debated but the priority is clear.

verses.text: Again, you have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not swear falsely, but shall perform your oaths to the Lord.’
verses.comment: Origin in Mosaic law prohibiting false oaths.

verses.text: But I say to you, do not swear at all, either by heaven, for it is the throne of God;
verses.comment: Jesus commands truthfulness without recourse to oaths, teaching integrity.

verses.text: or by the earth, for it is his footstool; or by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King.
verses.comment: All creation belongs to God; swearing by created things cannot add authority.

verses.text: And do not swear by your head, for you cannot make one hair white or black.
verses.comment: Human inability to alter creation highlights dependency on God alone.

verses.text: Let your word be ‘Yes, yes’ or ‘No, no’; anything more comes from the evil one.
verses.comment: Simple, honest speech is a mark of spiritual purity.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, ‘An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.’
verses.comment: Mosaic code taught proportionate justice; Jesus now points higher.

verses.text: But I say to you, do not resist an evil person. If someone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also.
verses.comment: Jesus advocates radical non-retaliation, exemplified by his own suffering; spiritual interpretation sees this as invitation to supererogatory virtue.

verses.text: And if anyone wants to sue you and take your tunic, let him have your cloak as well.
verses.comment: Self-sacrificial generosity and detachment from material goods are taught here.

verses.text: And if anyone forces you to go one mile, go with him two.
verses.comment: Going 'the extra mile' originates here; open-handed love transcends mere justice.

verses.text: Give to the one who asks you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you.
verses.comment: Generosity echoes Old Testament commands, now radicalized.

verses.text: You have heard that it was said, ‘Love your neighbor and hate your enemy.’
verses.comment: Only love of neighbor is found in the Old Testament; 'hate your enemy' was a common tradition but never divine command.

verses.text: But I say to you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you,
verses.comment: Christ’s teaching deepens love to include even enemies, paralleling his example on the cross.

verses.text: so that you may be sons of your Father who is in heaven. For he causes his sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the just and the unjust.
verses.comment: Imitating God’s unmerited grace is the sign of true spiritual sonship.

verses.text: For if you love those who love you, what reward do you have? Even the tax collectors do the same.
verses.comment: True Christian love exceeds social norms and human reciprocity.

verses.text: And if you greet only your brothers, what more are you doing than others? Do not even the Gentiles do the same?
verses.comment: Universal love is distinguished from mere clan loyalty, preparing disciples for a worldwide mission.

verses.text: Therefore, be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect.
verses.comment: Perfection—spiritual maturity and wholeness—comes through participation in God's holiness, not mere external compliance. Christ calls for growth in virtue and love through God's grace, a life-long process in the community of faith.
